title: Control empresarial de capitales purchases $4.3 million in PBF Energy stock
author: Investing.com
excerpt: Control empresarial de capitales purchases $4.3 million in PBF Energy stock
text: In a recent move, Control Empresarial de Capitales S.A. de C.V., a significant shareholder in PBF Energy Inc. (NYSE:), acquired 150,000 shares of the company's Class A common stock. The purchase, made on November 1, 2024, was executed at a weighted average price of $28.66 per share, with prices ranging from $28.54 to $28.75. This transaction amounts to a total value of approximately $4.3 million. Following this acquisition, Control Empresarial de Capitales now holds a total of 26,112,498 shares in PBF Energy. The Slim Family, beneficiaries of a trust owning all voting equity securities of Control Empresarial, may be deemed to indirectly own these shares. This holding represents about 22.7% of PBF Energy's outstanding Class A common shares, as reported in the company's recent Form 10-Q filing. In other recent news, PBF Energy experienced a challenging third quarter in 2024, reporting an adjusted net loss of $1.50 per share and an adjusted EBITDA loss of $60.1 million. These results were primarily due to weaker refining margins and a $29 million loss from its equity investment in St. Bernard Renewables. Despite these setbacks, PBF Energy returned $104 million to shareholders and announced a 10% increase in its quarterly dividend to $0.275 per share, signaling confidence in its financial stability. Mizuho (NYSE:) Securities, in response to these developments, has revised its price target for PBF Energy to $33 from the previous $36, maintaining a neutral rating on the stock. This adjustment reflects the firm's cautious outlook on the refining industry's near to medium-term prospects, based on a net asset value (NAV) approach. PBF Energy's fourth quarter guidance indicates a decrease in volume due to scheduled maintenance at the Chalmette refinery and adjustments for current economic conditions. However, the company is optimistic about 2025, expecting relief from refinery closures and easing geopolitical tensions. PBF Energy is also targeting $200 million in run rate cash savings by the end of 2025 and anticipates capital expenditures for the year to be between $750 million to $800 million. These are the recent developments for PBF Energy, a key player in the oil refining sector. Despite facing market challenges, the company remains strategically positioned for growth and is confident in its long-term prospects.
